tit.e: Ranpeki (people who devoted themselves to Dutch or Western learning)
Ranpeki (people who devoted themselves to Dutch or Western learning)

sen.j: 蘭癖（らんぺき）は江戸時代、蘭学に傾注したり、オランダ式（あるいは西洋式）の習俗を憧憬・模倣するような人を指した呼び名である。
sen.e: "Ranpeki" is a nickname for people who devoted themselves to Dutch studies and adored and copied Dutch (or Western) manners and customs in the Edo Period.
Ranpeki refers to people who devoted themselves to Western learning, or yearned and copied Dutch (or Western) manners and customs in the Edo period.
Ranpeki refers to people who devoted themselves to Western learning, or yearned and copied Dutch (or Western) manners and customs in the Edo period.

sen.j: 蘭癖の出現
sen.e: Emergence of Ranpeki
Emergence of Ranpeki
Emergence of Ranpeki

sen.j: 徳川吉宗の享保の改革により、洋書輸入が一部解禁された。
sen.e: The ban on importing Western books was partially lifted as a result of the Kyoho Reform implemented by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The ban on importing Western books was partially lifted as a result of the Kyoho Reform implemented by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.
The ban on importing Western books was partially lifted as a result of the Kyoho Reform implemented by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: このことから江戸中期以降、蘭学研究が盛んになった。
sen.e: Because of this, Dutch studies prospered from the mid-Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Because of this, Western studies prospered from the mid-Edo period.
Because of this, Western studies prospered from the mid-Edo period.

sen.j: しかし、学問的な興味だけではなく、生活様式や風俗・身なりに至るまで、オランダ流（洋式）のものを憧憬し、模倣するような者まで現れるようになった。
sen.e: However, those who not only had academic interest but also adored and copied Dutch (or Western) things ranging from a mode of living to its manners, customs, and personal appearance came to appear.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: However, not only from academic interest, but also the yearning of their way of living, customs, and personal appearance, people copied the Dutch (or Western) style came to appear.
However, not only from academic interest, but also the yearning of their way of living, customs, and personal appearance, people copied the Dutch (or Western) style came to appear.

sen.j: そして、中には蘭語名まで持つ者まであった。
sen.e: And some of them even had Dutch names.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: And some of them even had Dutch names.
And some of them even had Dutch names.

sen.j: ただし、江戸時代中期から後期にかけての史料においては「蘭癖」という語の使用例は多くない。
sen.e: However, there are not many examples of the usage of the term, 'ranpeki,' in the historical records of the mid- to late Edo Period.
However, there are not many examples of the usage of the term, 'ranpeki,' in the historical records of the mid- to late Edo period.
However, there are not many examples of the usage of the term, 'ranpeki,' in the historical records of the mid- to late Edo period.

sen.j: 幕末期にいたって、水戸藩など攘夷派から「西洋かぶれ」の意で、蔑称として用いられる例が多くなった。
sen.e: In the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, it began to be used often as a disparaging name to refer to 'seiyo kabure' (ultra-Westernized persons) by joi-ha faction (the antiforeigner faction) like the Mito Domain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, it began to be used often as a disparaging name to refer to 'seiyo kabure' (ultra-Westernized persons) by joi-ha faction (the antiforeigner faction) like the Mito clan.

In the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, it began to be used often as a disparaging name to refer to 'seiyo kabure' (ultra-Westernized persons) by joi-ha faction (the antiforeigner faction) like the Mito clan.

sen.j: そして、明治時代になって普及した語といえる。
sen.e: And it became widespread in the Meiji Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: And it became widespread in the Meiji period.
And it became widespread in the Meiji period.

sen.j: すなわち「鎖国」などと同様に、明治以降になって普及した後に、それ以前の"蘭癖"的人物もこの語で形容されるようになったものであろう。
sen.e: That is, similar to 'sakoku' (national isolation) and other expressions, after it came into wide use in the Meiji Period, it came to describe the people who were "ranpeki-"like before then.
That is, similar to 'sakoku' (national isolation) and other expressions, after it came into wide use in the Meiji period, it came to describe the people who were "ranpeki-"like before then.
That is, similar to 'sakoku' (national isolation) and other expressions, after it came into wide use in the Meiji period, it came to describe the people who were "ranpeki-"like before then.

sen.j: 吉雄耕牛・平賀源内・大槻玄沢らのように、オランダ正月と呼ばれる、太陽暦で祝う正月行事などの西洋式習俗を楽しむ学者などもいた。
sen.e: There were also scholars like Kogyu YOSHIO, Gennai HIRAGA, and Gentaku OTSUKI who enjoyed Western manners and customs, including New Year celebrations according to the solar calendar called Dutch New Year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: There were also scholars like Kogyu YOSHIO, Gennai HIRAGA, and Gentaku OTSUKI who enjoyed Western manners and customs, including New Year celebrations according to the solar calendar called Dutch New Year.

There were also scholars like Kogyu YOSHIO, Gennai HIRAGA, and Gentaku OTSUKI who enjoyed Western manners and customs, including New Year celebrations according to the solar calendar called Dutch New Year.

sen.j: だが、蘭書やオランダの文物・珍品は非常に高価であった。
sen.e: However, Dutch books, cultural products, and rare articles were very expensive.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: However, Dutch books, cultural products, and rare articles were very expensive.
However, Dutch books, cultural products, and rare articles were very expensive.

sen.j: そして、購入には莫大な経済力が必要だった。
sen.e: And buying them required vast economic power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: And buying them required vast economic power.
And buying them required vast economic power.

sen.j: そのため、「蘭癖」と称される人物には、学者よりも大商人や大名、上級武士などが多い。
sen.e: For this reason, there were more wealthy merchants, daimyo (feudal lords), and upper-class samurai (Japanese warriors) than scholars among those who were called 'ranpeki.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: For this reason, there were more wealthy merchants, daimyo (feudal lords), and upper-class samurai (Japanese warriors) than scholars among those who were called 'ranpeki.'
For this reason, there were more wealthy merchants, daimyo (feudal lords), and upper-class samurai (Japanese warriors) than scholars among those who were called 'ranpeki.'

sen.j: 特に藩主の場合は「蘭癖大名」などと呼ばれる。
sen.e: Particularly, when they were feudal lords, they were called 'ranpeki daimyo' (daimyo who were devoted to Dutch or Western culture).
Particularly, when they were feudal lords, they were called 'ranpeki daimyo' (daimyo who were devoted to Dutch or Western culture).
Particularly, when they were feudal lords, they were called 'ranpeki daimyo' (daimyo who were devoted to Dutch or Western culture).

sen.j: 殿様趣味の枠を超えて、自ら蘭学研究を行ったり、学問の奨励するなどした。
sen.e: Their interest transcended lordly outside interests, including their personal engagement in Dutch studies, promotion of learning, etc.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Their interest transcended lordly outside interests, including their personal engagement in Western studies, promotion of learning, and so on.
Their interest transcended lordly outside interests, including their personal engagement in Western studies, promotion of learning, and so on.

sen.j: 文化的な評価は高い。
sen.e: And its cultural value was high.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: They were highly-acclaimed in cultural term.
They were highly-acclaimed in cultural term.

sen.j: その反面、蘭学趣味が高じて藩財政を窮地に陥れるなどの傾向も見られる（もちろん例外もある）。
sen.e: On the other hand, however, their interest in Dutch studies also tended to grow in intensity, driving their domains into a financial corner (although there were, of course, exceptions).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: On the other hand, however, their interest in Western studies also tended to grow in intensity, driving their clans into a financial corner (although there were, of course, exceptions).
On the other hand, however, their interest in Western studies also tended to grow in intensity, driving their clans into a financial corner (although there were, of course, exceptions).

sen.j: 蘭癖大名の分布としては、主に九州の外様大名が多い。
sen.e: With respect to the distribution of the ranpeki daimyo, many of them were mainly tozama daimyo (outside daimyo who were not hereditary vassals of the Tokugawa family) in Kushu.
In the distribution of ranpeki daimyo, they were mainly tozama daimyo (outside daimyo who were not hereditary vassals of the Tokugawa family) in Kyushu region.
sen.cmt: スペル、用語を変更しました。
sen.e: In the distribution of ranpeki daimyo, they were mainly tozama daimyo (outside daimyo who were not hereditary vassals of the Tokugawa family) in Kyushu region.

sen.j: これはオランダに開かれた港・長崎が近く、蘭書や輸入品の入手が容易だったことと無縁ではないだろう。
sen.e: This is thought to be related to the fact that they were close to the port that was open to Holland, Nagasaki, and they could easily obtain Dutch books and imported commodities.
This is thought to be related to the fact that they were close to the port that was open to Holland, Nagasaki, and they could easily obtain Dutch books and imported commodities.
This is thought to be related to the fact that they were close to the port that was open to Holland, Nagasaki, and they could easily obtain Dutch books and imported commodities.

sen.j: その点、関東に所領を持つ譜代大名の堀田正睦はかなり例外的である。
sen.e: In this regard, Masayoshi HOTTA, who was a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa family) holding a domain in Kanto, is highly exceptional.
In this regard, Masayoshi HOTTA, who was a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa family) holding a territory in Kanto, was highly exceptional.
In this regard, Masayoshi HOTTA, who was a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa family) holding a territory in Kanto, was highly exceptional.

sen.j: このような蘭癖大名の典型例として知られる代表的な人物として、薩摩藩主島津重豪が挙げられる。
sen.e: Representative individuals known as typical examples of the ranpeki daimyo include the lord of the Satsuma Domain, Shigehide SHIMAZU.
Representative individuals known as typical examples of the ranpeki daimyo include the lord of the Satsuma clan, Shigehide SHIMAZU.
Representative individuals known as typical examples of the ranpeki daimyo include the lord of the Satsuma clan, Shigehide SHIMAZU.

sen.j: 重豪の子である奥平昌高・黒田長溥や、曾孫の島津斉彬もまた、重豪の影響を受けた。
sen.e: Shigehide's children, Masataka OKUDAIRA and Nagahiro KURODA, as well as his great-grandchild, Nariakira SHIMAZU, were also influenced by Shigehide.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Shigehide's children, Masataka OKUDAIRA and Nagahiro KURODA, as well as his great-grandchild, Nariakira SHIMAZU, were also influenced by Shigehide.
Shigehide's children, Masataka OKUDAIRA and Nagahiro KURODA, as well as his great-grandchild, Nariakira SHIMAZU, were also influenced by Shigehide.

sen.j: そのためかそれぞれ蘭癖大名と称されるほどであった。
sen.e: Perhaps because of this, each of them was described as ranpeku daimyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Perhaps because of this, each of them was described as ranpeki daimyo.
Perhaps because of this, each of them was described as ranpeki daimyo.

sen.j: 文明開化以降は、「西洋かぶれ」も珍しい物ではなくなった。
sen.e: After civilization and enlightenment, 'seiyo kabure' ceased to be something unusual.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: After civilization and enlightenment, 'seiyo kabure' ceased to be something unusual.
After civilization and enlightenment, 'seiyo kabure' ceased to be something unusual.

sen.j: 蘭癖と称されることもなくなった。
sen.e: And it was no longer described as ranpeki.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: And they were no longer described as ranpeki.
And they were no longer described as ranpeki.

sen.j: 主な蘭癖の例
sen.e: Main Examples of Ranpeki
Main Examples of Ranpeki
Main Examples of Ranpeki

sen.j: 著名な蘭癖大名
sen.e: Prominent ranpeki daimyo
Prominent ranpeki daimyo
Prominent ranpeki daimyo

sen.j: 細川重賢（熊本藩主、1721年 - 1785年）
sen.e: Shigekata HOSOKAWA (the lord of the Kumamoto Domain, 1721-1785)
Shigekata HOSOKAWA (the lord of the Kumamoto clan, 1721 to 1785)
Shigekata HOSOKAWA (the lord of the Kumamoto clan, 1721 to 1785)

sen.j: 島津重豪（薩摩藩主、1745年 - 1833年）
sen.e: Shigehide SHIMAZU (the lord of the Satsuma Domain, 1745-1833)
Shigehide SHIMAZU (the lord of the Satsuma clan, 1745 to 1833)
Shigehide SHIMAZU (the lord of the Satsuma clan, 1745 to 1833)

sen.j: 佐竹義敦（久保田藩主、1748年 - 1785年、曙山）
sen.e: Yoshiatsu SATAKE (the lord of the Kubota Domain, 1748-1785, Shozan)
Yoshiatsu SATAKE (also referred as Shozan, the lord of the Kubota clan, 1748 to 1785)
Yoshiatsu SATAKE (also referred as Shozan, the lord of the Kubota clan, 1748 to 1785)

sen.j: 朽木昌綱（福知山藩主、1750年 - 1802年）
sen.e: Masatsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Fukuchiyama Domain, 1750-1802)
Masatsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Fukuchiyama clan, 1750 to 1802)
Masatsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Fukuchiyama clan, 1750 to 1802)

sen.j: 松浦清（平戸藩主、1760年 - 1841年）
sen.e: Kiyoshi MATSURA (the lord of the Hirado Domain, 1760-1841)
Kiyoshi MATSURA (the lord of the Hirado clan, 1760 to 1841)
Kiyoshi MATSURA (the lord of the Hirado clan, 1760 to 1841)

sen.j: 奥平昌高（中津藩主、1781年 - 1855年、島津重豪の次男）
sen.e: Masataka OKUDAIRA (the lord of the Nakatsu Domain, 1781-1855, Shigehide SHIMAZU's second son)
Masataka OKUDAIRA (the lord of the Nakatsu clan, 1781 to 1855, Shigehide SHIMAZU's second son)
Masataka OKUDAIRA (the lord of the Nakatsu clan, 1781 to 1855, Shigehide SHIMAZU's second son)

sen.j: 黒田斉清（福岡藩主、1795年 - 1851年）
sen.e: Narikiyo KURODA (the lord of the Fukuoka Domain, 1795-1851)
Narikiyo KURODA (the lord of the Fukuoka clan, 1795 to 1851)
Narikiyo KURODA (the lord of the Fukuoka clan, 1795 to 1851)

sen.j: 島津斉彬（薩摩藩主、1809年 - 1858年、島津重豪の曾孫）
sen.e: Nariakira SHIMAZU (the lord of the Satsuma Domain, 1809-1858, Shigehide SHIMAZU's great-grandchild)
Nariakira SHIMAZU (the lord of the Satsuma clan, 1809 to 1858, Shigehide SHIMAZU's great-grandchild)
Nariakira SHIMAZU (the lord of the Satsuma clan, 1809 to 1858, Shigehide SHIMAZU's great-grandchild)

sen.j: 堀田正睦（老中・佐倉藩主、1810年 - 1864年）
sen.e: Masayoshi HOTTA, (Shogun's chief councilor and the lord of the Sakura Domain, 1810-1864)
Masayoshi HOTTA, (Roju [member of shogun's council of elders] and the lord of the Sakura clan, 1810 to 1864)
Masayoshi HOTTA, (Roju [member of shogun's council of elders] and the lord of the Sakura clan, 1810 to 1864)

sen.j: 黒田長溥（福岡藩主、1811年 - 1887年、島津重豪の九男、黒田斉清の養子）
sen.e: Nagahiro KURODA (the lord of the Fukuoka Domain, 1811-1887, Shigehide SHIMAZU's ninth son, Narikiyo KURODA's adopted heir)
Nagahiro KURODA (the lord of the Fukuoka clan, 1811 to 1887, Shigehide SHIMAZU's ninth son, Narikiyo KURODA's adopted son)

sen.j: 鍋島直正（佐賀藩主、1815年 - 1871年）
sen.e: Naomasa NABESHIMA (the lord of the Saga Domain, 1815-1871)
Naomasa NABESHIMA (the lord of the Saga clan, 1815 to 1871)

sen.j: 大名以外

sen.j: 司馬江漢（絵師、1738年 - 1818年）
sen.e: Kokan SHIBA (a painter, 1738-1818)

sen.j: 熊谷義比（長州藩御用商人、1795年 - 1860年）
sen.e: Yoshikazu KUMAYA (a purveyor to the Choshu Domain, 1795-1860)
Yoshikazu KUMAYA (a purveyor of the Choshu clan, 1795 to 1860)
Yoshikazu KUMAYA (a purveyor of the Choshu clan, 1795 to 1860)

sen.j: 山片重芳（升屋、大坂商人、仙台藩御用、山片蟠桃の主人）
sen.e: Shigeyoshi YAMAGATA (a money exchanger, a Osaka dealer, a purveyor to the Sendai Domain, the master of Banto YAMAGATA)
Shigeyoshi YAMAGATA (a money exchanger, a merchant in Osaka, a purveyor of the Sendai clan, the master of Banto YAMAGATA)

sen.j: 渡辺崋山（田原藩家老、1793年 - 1841年）
sen.e: Kazan WATANABE (the chief retainer of the Tahara Domain, 1793-1841)
Kazan WATANABE (the chief retainer of the Tahara clan, 1793 to 1841)

sen.j: 三宅友信（田原藩主三宅康保の父、1793年 - 1841年）
sen.e: Tomonobu MIYAKE (the father of the lord of the Tahara Domain, Yasuyoshi MIYAKE)
Tomonobu MIYAKE (the father of the lord of the Tahara clan, Yasuyoshi MIYAKE, 1793 to 1841)

sen.j: 江川英龍（伊豆国韮山代官、1801年 - 1855年）
sen.e: Hidetatsu EGAWA (the local magistrate of Nirayama of Izu Province)
Hidetatsu EGAWA (the local magistrate of Nirayama of Izu Province, 1801 to 1855)

sen.e: Masanori MURATA (the chief retainer of the Saga Domain, 1815-1874)
